head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #23

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #23 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks on board the Nancy hired Transport on her return passage to Makinac or St Josephs in the month of October 1813[.]

First part of this 24 hours the wind abates, but still roolling gunnel in, at ½ past 7 AM set the fore sail & fore top sail close reefed, wind WNW, starboard tacks aboard – cloudy cold weather – at 10 shook a reef out of the fore top sail, loosed main top sail & flying jibb to boom end, the West shore in sight distant about 15 miles to the southward of the point of Bark, at noon nearly calm, shook the reefs out of the M: T: sail & main sail, set fore the gallant sail, wind WSW – cloudy weather but more mild than the morning (during the gale pumped ship every 2 hours – makes no more than usual[)] – at 4 set M: T: G: sail – coiled the best bower cable below which could not be done previously from its being wet – at 3 bafling winds, at 4 wind at SSE put before it course NNW cloudy weather threatining rain, handed the fore sail & shook the reef out of the F: T: sail at 6 wind, East, at 10 took a reef in each of the topsails & handed Top gallant sails at 11 set the fore sail wind NE cold & disagreeable with rain, handed the square sail – blows fresh.

First part of this 24 hours blows fresh at NE by N accompanied with rain at 4 AM close in with the highlands of Sable distant about 3 miles. The Thunder Bay Islands in sight distant about 8 miles bearg N, wore ship to the eastward wind NNE with a mountainous sea carried away the boom guy & stranded the Main spring stay, cut & spliced again handed the main top sail flying jibb, at 5 set the flying jibb more moderate, at 6 ceases raining wind North – at 8 cold raw weather – at noon wind NNW with snow at 2 PM wind NW & blows a gale close reefed & handed the fore top sail – fore-sail flying jibb double reefed the main sail & hove the vessel too, at 8 wore ship to SW starboard tacks aboard still continues to blow very hard – with rain, sleet & snow[.]

First part of this 24 Hours blows fresh at WNW & cold still trying under the jibb & double reefed main sail[.] Kept the pump a going every 2 hours – at ½ past noon having occasion to put some service on the main peak ty, which had already made a hole in the main sail, Joseph Lamotte

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
